moves.1. e4 Nf6: What can we say? This man was once champion of the world...
moves.2. e5 Nd5: The standard continuation; 2. ... Ne4 3. d4, also...
moves.3. d4: It is too soon, for 3. c4 Nb6 4. c5 Nd5, although 5. Bc4 can give nice play... White should not let his pawns advance to far...
moves.4. Nf3: Still, no c4; this might be a nice move in the future, for black, to worry about... This is the Flohr variation, my favourite method, of handling this...
moves.4... Bg4: I would prefer Bf5, followed by Nc6, and Nb4, to deregulate whites play with an early attack on c2...
moves.6... Ne7: A peculiar move... Also after 6. ... Nb6 - the best move - follows 7. exd6 cxd6 8. d5...
moves.7. exd6 Qxd6: Forced, now... After cxd6, d5, Nd7 (or first exd5, cxd5), dxe6, black's position is quickly deteriorating...
moves.8... a6: Loss of tempo, white is not considering Nb5... Better 8. ... Bxf3 9. Bxf3 Nbc6 10. Nb5 Qd7... Best is 8. ... Nf5, followed by Be7, and castling...
moves.9... b6: Black cannot afford Qxb7 right now, without any real development... Bxf3 would have made things worse...
moves.10... Nbc6 11. Rd1: The best way, to throw black off balance...
moves.12. h3: Temporizing; 12. Qc2 Bf5 might give him any ideas... Though 13. Ne4 works fine... Notice, we are also robbing black from Nf5, after Bxf3, etc., due to g2-g4...
moves.12... Bh5: Totally missing the point; there was still 12. ... Bf5, or 12. ... Bxf3 13. Bxf3 0-0-0...
moves.13... Bg6 14. Ne4: Contemplating Bf4, so 0-0-0 is in order... Or Rd8...
moves.14... Rd8: Also 14. ... Qa5 might have given some comfort, after 15. Bd2 Qh5...
moves.15. a3: Of course... This is the last reality check for black, after 15. ... Bxe4 16. Qxe4 Qa4, it might just hold...
moves.16... Rd7: Now, it is too late for Bxe4, Qxe4, Qf5, Qe3...
moves.17... Rxd4: Not any better is 17. ... Nxd4 18. Nxd7 Nbc6...
moves.18. Nxg6 Nxg6 19. Bxc7: Relentless... Though the material is still equal, black is utterly lost...
Toughest is 24. ... Bc5 25. Bf1! h6! 26. Ra7 Qb2...
